subject: Re: [junit] Re: Randomly Ordered Repeating Test Suite
msgSnippet: ... Good, because that won t work.  The production code gets used in many paths, and I decided the asserts in it would be to generic to help. ... That s
messageBody:
Chad Woolley wrote:

>Actually, I wasn't meaning asserts outside your tests. I meant in your
>failing test, before and after the invocation of the Class Under Test.
>However, use whatever works - and the assert approach may not work at all.
>
>
>
Good, because that won't work. The production code gets used in many
paths, and I decided the asserts in it would be to "generic" to help.

>Also, I'll mention another idea, although it may be anathema to this
>list. If you can somehow DETECT the failure, put a breakpoint in your
>application (System.in or something to that effect), and then fire up
>your debugger and inspect the state of everything.
>
>I know that many people on this list (and Dave Astel's in his fine book)
>say you shouldn't need the debugger if you TDD intensively enough. I
>myself am unfortunately not to that level yet, and I often find it
>useful to fire up the debugger.
>
>Whatever approach you use, I think the general idea is to gradually
>narrow down the scope of the unknown failure until you can see what is
>the root cause.
>
>
>
That's certainly the cause. The problem is that I only see it once a
day or so, so narrowing it down may take a while. I was hoping
(originally) that runing it "a lot", under "random conditions" might
make it show itself more than once a day.


>Hope this helps,
>Chad
>
>David Corbin wrote:
>
>
>>Prefectly reasonable suggestion. I'll give it a try. For some reason, I
>>don't think of asserts outside my tests. (I'm don't like the clutter).
>>Chad Woolley wrote:
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>>>Probably not the advice you want, but have you tried to use asserts to
>>>>get more info? Whatever the failure is, keep adding asserts about
>>>>anything you can think of regarding the expected state of the app and
>>>>objects under test. Even (especially?) add ones for things you may
>>>>think are obviously working correctly. This may give you some clues to
>>>>the problem.
>>>>
>>>>David Corbin wrote:
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>>>I've got one tests which fails sporadically, and I cannot figure out any
>>>>>>reason for it to be non-deterministic in MY code. I've added some
>>>>>>logging statements, but It's hard to get to fail.
>>>>>>
>>>>>>
